p.s: Teacher: Now, let's see how to indicate possession or ownership in German.
Teacher: To indicate possession or ownership, we add an "-s" at the end of the noun
Teacher: To say "Christian's car", simply say "Christians Auto"
Teacher: Just like English, but without the apostrophe. So how would you say "Heidi's dress"?
Student: Heidis kleid
Teacher: How about "Heidi's dress is expensive"? What was the word for expensive?
Student: teuer
Teacher: So how will you say - "Heidi's dress is expensive"?
Student: Heidis Kleid ist teuer
Teacher: Wonderful. Now try saying "Heidi's dress is expensive because she bought it in Italy"?
Student: Heidis Kleid ist teuer, weil, sie es in Italien gekauft hat.
Teacher: Excellent! Proper nouns like names follow this simple pattern of adding an s at the end of the noun
Teacher: Now let's see how to say, "the father's car", instead of "Christian's car"
Teacher: In German, instead of saying, "the father's car", we say "the car of the father"
Teacher: So how does one say "The father"?
Student: Der Vater
Teacher: Great. Now add an "s" to both words, just like we did earlier
Teacher: If you add an "s" to der, what do we get?
Student: ders?
Teacher: Close, but not quite
Teacher: We added s to der, which makes it des
Teacher: And when we add an "s" to Vater, it becomes?
Student: Vaters?
Teacher: Excellent, Vater becomes Vaters, Vaters
Teacher: So, everything together now - "the car of the father"
Student: Das Auto, des Vaters
Teacher: Right. Das Auto, des Vaters, good
Teacher: Now how would you say, "the computer of my uncle"?
Student: Der Computer, meines Onkels
Teacher: So how will you say - "the computer of my uncle is slow"?
Student: Der Computer, meines Onkels, ist langsam
Teacher: Very nice. Now try saying "the computer of my uncle is slow because it is very old"
Student: Der Computer, meines Onkels, ist langsam, weil, es sehr alt ist
Teacher: How would you say, "The room of the hotel, is too small"?
Student: Das Zimmer des Hotels ist zu klein
Teacher: Well done!
Teacher: How about, "I love, the dog of my uncle"?
Student: Ich liebe, der Hund, meines Onkels
Teacher: Aren't you forgetting something?
Teacher: What happens to der Hund, when it is the object?
Student: Oh sorry. Den Hund
Teacher: Once more, "I love, the dog of my uncle"
Student: Ich liebe, den Hund, meines Onkels
Teacher: Wonderful!
Teacher: How would you say, "I have seen, the teacher of the girl"?
Student: Ich habe, die Lehrerin, des Mädchens, gesehen.
Teacher: Good! Mädchen, is neutral and follows the same rule. Just add "-s" to both words
Teacher: How would you say, "Can you give me, the number of your mobile phone"?
Student: "Kannst du mir, die Nummer, deines Handys geben?
Teacher: Right
